command of [[Pakistan Air Force]]{{cite news | last =Abbas | first =Zafar | coauthors = | title =Pakistan gets women combat pilots | newspaper =BBC News | location =Islamabad | page =1 | language =| publisher =BBC News, Islamabad | date =30 March 2006 | url =http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/4861666.stm | accessdate =September 2, 2012 }} and women in [[Pakistan Army]] have been trained in combat missions, particularly in sniper, airborne and infantry warfare.{{cite web | last =Staff editorial report | first = | authorlink = | title =Pakistan army to turns to women for combat | website =Indian Defence Journal | publisher =Indian Defence Journal | date =April 26, 2006 | url =http://www.india-defence.com/reports-1797 | doi = | accessdate =September 2, 2012 }} The [[Pakistan Navy]] is currently the only uniform service branch where women are restricted to serve in the combat missions especially in the submarine force command, rather they are appointed and served in the operation involving the [[military logistics]], operational planning, staff development and the senior administrative offices, particularly in the regional and central headquarters.{{cite news | last =Staff report | first = | coauthors = | title =Splendid passing-out parade held for smartly turned out naval officers | newspaper =Tribune Express | location =Pakistan Naval Academy | page =1 | publisher =Tribune Express | date =July 5, 2011 | url =http://tribune.com.pk/story/202397/splendid-passing-out-parade-held-for-smartly-turned-out-naval-officers/ | accessdate =September 2, 2012 }} ===Philippines=== {{Main|Women in the Philippine military}} From 1993 onward, women served only in [[Women's Army Corps|Women's Army Auxiliary Corps]] of [[Philippine military]]. In 1993, women were granted the right to serve as combat soldiers with the passage of Republic Act No. 7192 and the first batch started the training in the [[Philippine Military Academy]] in April that year. ===Saudi Arabia=== Applications for certain non-combat roles were opened to women in February, 2018.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-43197048|title=Saudi Arabia allows women to join army|date=26 February 2018|publisher=|via=www.bbc.com}} ===Singapore=== Singapore allows women to serve in combat roles, although females are not conscripted. ===Sri Lanka=== [[Sri Lanka Air Force]] (SLAF) was the first service of the Sri Lankan military to allow women to serve, accepting female recruits to the [[Sri Lanka Volunteer Air Force]] in 1972. The Sri Lanka Army followed in 1979 with the establishment of the [[Sri Lanka Army Women's Corps]] (SLAWC). Since then, each service has for both administrative and practical reasons maintained separate units for women. These are the SLAWC and the SLAF Women's Wing; the [[Sri Lanka Navy]] does not have a specific name for women's units. In order to maintain discipline, all three services have women [[Military police|MPs]] attached to their respective military police/provost corps. Currently, female personnel of all three services play an active part in ongoing operations. However, there are certain limitations in 'direct combat' duties such as [[special forces]], pilot branch, naval fast attack squadrons. These are only a few restrictions; female personnel have been tasked with many front line duties and attached to combat units such as [[paratroops]], [[Sri Lanka Air Force Regiment|SLAF Regiment]], as well as undertaken support services such as [[Control tower|control tower operators]], [[Electronic warfare|electronic warfare technicians]], radio material teletypewriters, [[Auto mechanic|automotive mechanics]], [[Assault Support|aviation supply personnel]], [[cryptographers]], [[physician|doctors]], [[combat medic]]s, [[lawyers]], [[Combat engineering|engineers]] and [[Aerial photography|aerial photographers]]. In the [[Sri Lanka Navy]] female personnel were at first limited to the medical branch, however currently both lady officers and female rates are able to join any branch of service including the executive branch. With the escalation of the [[Sri Lankan civil war]], many female personnel have come under enemy fire both directly and indirectly thus taking many casualties including fatalities. As of 2008 there were three female officers of the rank of [[Major General]] and one [[Commodore (rank)|Commodore]]. The [[Department of Civil Defence (Sri Lanka)|Sri Lanka Civil Defence Force]], formerly the Sri Lanka Home Guard, has been open to women recruits since 1988. In 1993, these guardswomen were issued firearms and deployed to protect their home towns and villages against attacks by [[LTTE]]. As a result, there have been many casualties (including fatalities) from attacks. ===Thailand=== Thailand has recently begun recruiting and training women to conduct counter-insurgency operations (c. 2007).{{cite news| url=http://edition.cnn.com/2007/WORLD/asiapcf/03/18/thailand.women.ap/ | work=CNN}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}} A ranger commander said that when women are protesting, "It is better for women to do the talking. Male soldiers look tough and aggressive. When women go and talk, people tend to be more relaxed". === United Arab Emirates === [[File:Khalifa Academy Graduation.jpg|thumb|260x260px|Emirati female cadets parade during a graduation ceremony at Khalifa bin Zayed Air College.]] The UAE hosts the Gulf region’s first military college for women, Khawla Bint Al Azwar Military School has been open since 1991 under the late [[Zayed bin Sultan Al Nahyan]]. Females were granted the same training and responsibilities as their male counterparts, and also play a major role in humanitarian assistance and peacekeeping operations. Emirati women have reached senior ranks within the [[UAE Armed Forces]], especially in the Air Force combat units. A great example of the achievements of Emirati women is Major [[Mariam al-Mansouri]], The first female fighter pilot in the [[United Arab Emirates]] and the [[Arab World]]. She made international headlines for leading the UAE's mission to fight ISIS.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/uae/government/emirati-woman-who-reached-for-the-skies|title=Emirati woman who reached for the skies ... {{!}} The National|website=www.thenational.ae|access-date=2016-05-19}}{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/uae/general/uae-women-prove-competency-in-military-1.1045873|title=UAE women prove competency in military|last=WAM|date=2012-07-08|website=GulfNews|access-date=2016-05-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/uae/uae-armed-forces-women-honoured|title=UAE Armed Forces women honoured {{!}} The National|website=www.thenational.ae|access-date=2016-05-19}} In 2014, women were had the choice to be conscripted provided they have their parents’ consent. Military service is for 9 months and is optional for women aged 18 to 30 and is mandatory for men aged between 18 and 30 and is for 1 year.{{cite web|url=https://www.wam.ae/en/news/emirates/1395268672475.html|title=Khawla Bint Al Azwar Military School is ready to welcome female conscripts {{!}} WAM|website=www.wam.ae|access-date=2016-05-19}} ==Europe== ===Denmark=== Women were employed in the Danish armed forces as early as 1934 with the Ground Observer Corps, Danish Women's Army Corps and Naval Corps in 1946 and the Women's Air Force since 1953. In 1962, the Danish parliament passed laws allowing women to volunteer in the regular Danish armed forces as long as they did not serve in units experiencing direct combat. 1971 saw the enlistment of women as non-commissioned officers, with military academies allowing women in 1974. In 1978, based on the reports of studies on the topic, women were allowed to enlist in an all areas of the Danish armed forces, with combat trials in the eighties exploring the capabilities of women in combat. In 1998, laws were passed allowing women to sample military life in the same way as conscripted men, however without being completely open to conscription. Since then females have served in infantry units in both Iraq and in combat in Afghanistan.{{cite web|url=http://sorensjogren.com/2012/the-problem-with-women-in-combat-units/|title=HugeDomains.com - SoreNsJogRen.com is for sale (Sore Ns Jog Ren)|website=sorensjogren.com}} Women in the Danish military come under the command of the Chief of Defense.{{cite web|url=http://www.nato.int/ims/2001/win/denmark.htm|title=NATO/IMS: Committee on Women in the NATO Forces: Denmark|publisher=}} As of January 2010, women make up 5% of the army, 6.9% of the navy, and 8.6% of air force personnel. ===Finland=== [[File:Naispunakaartilainen.jpg|thumb|125px|upright|Red Guard during the [[Finnish Civil War]]]] The [[Finnish Defense Forces]] does not conscript women. However, since 1995, women between 18 and 30 years of age have the possibility of voluntarily undertaking military service in the Defence Forces or in the [[Finnish Border Guard|Border Guard]]. Women generally serve under the same conditions as men. [[File:Lottia ilmavalvontatehtävissä.jpg|thumb|left|Members of [[Lotta Svärd]] in air control duty during the [[Continuation War]]]] The history of women in the Finnish military is, however, far longer than just since 1995. During the [[Finnish Civil War]], the [[Red Guards (Finland)|Reds]] had several ''Naiskaarti'' (Women's Guard) units made of voluntary 16- to 35-year-old women, who were given rudimentary military training. The reactions on women in military were ambivalent during the Civil War. The non-combat duties in Finnish Defence Forces [[peace-keeping]] operations opened to women in 1991. Since 1995 the women are allowed to serve in all combat arms including front-line infantry and special forces both in Finland and in operations outside Finland. ===France=== [[File:Cantiniere1800s.jpg|thumb|A [[Cantinière]] with a male infantry soldier in Algeria, around 1845. Painting by Edouard Moreau.]] In the 1800s, women in the French military were responsible for preparing meals for soldiers, and were called [[cantinière]]s. They sold food to soldiers beyond that which was given to them as rations. Cantinières had commissions from the administrators of the regiments, and they were required to be married to a soldier of the regiment. They served near the front lines on active campaigns, and some served for as long as 30 years.{{cite web|title=Following the drums: Cantinieres|url=http://www.napoleon-series.org/military/organization/c_cantinieres.html|accessdate=August 14, 2011}} During the [[Wars of the French Revolution]], some women enlisted in the army, mainly in support roles. [[Angélique Brûlon|Marie-Angélique Duchemin]] is the first woman with a recorded rank in the French Army, being promoted Corporal and Acting Sergeant in 1794. She was promoted 2nd Lieutenant on the retired list in 1815. Duchemin is the first woman decorated with the [[Legion of Honor]], in 1851.{{fr}} [http://www.napoleon.org/fr/salle_lecture/biographies/files/duchemin_delage_2007.asp fondation Napoléon] The role of women in the French military grew in 1914 with the recruitment of women as medical personnel (Service de Santé des Armées). In 1939, they were authorized to enlist with the armed service branches, and in 1972 their status evolved to share the same ranks as those of men. [[Valérie André]], a neurosurgeon, became the first woman in France to attain the rank of three-star general as Médecin Général Inspecteur. A veteran of the [[French Resistance]], she served overseas in [[Indochina]]. During that period, she learned how to pilot a helicopter so that she could reach wounded soldiers who were trapped in the jungle. André is the first woman to have flown a helicopter in combat. She received many decorations for her achievements, including the highest rank of the [[Legion of Honour]]. She retired from active service in 1981. Today women can serve in every position in the French military, including submarines[http://en.rfi.fr/france/20171204-France-have-its-first-women-submariners-mission France have its first women submariners on mission], [[Radio France International]], december 2017. and combat infantry.[http://www.rfi.fr/france/20150223-journee-internationale-femme-militaire-commando-parachutiste-8-mars-defense A l'armée, une femme est un homme comme les autres], Radio France international, march 2015 {{fr}} make up around 15% of all service personnel in the combined branches of the French military. They are 11% of the Army forces, 13% for the Navy, 21% of the Air Force and 50% of the Medical Corps. This is the highest proportion of female personnel in Europe.{{cite web|title=Les femmes de la Defense|url=https://www.defense.gouv.fr/content/download/487432/7798345/version/1/file/Les+femmes+dans+larmee+francaise-diptyque.pdf|publisher=Ministry of Defense, Government of France|accessdate=February 12, 2018}} ===Germany=== Since the creation of the [[Bundeswehr]] in 1955, Germany had employed one of the most conservative gender-policies of any NATO country.{{Citation needed|date=April 2010}} That was generally regarded as a reaction to the deployment of young women at the end of [[World War II]]. Though women were exempt from direct combat functions in accordance with Nazi-ideology, several hundred thousand German women, along with young boys and sometimes girls (as [[Flakhelfer]]), served in Luftwaffe artillery units; their flak shot down thousands of Allied warplanes.[http://americanhistoryprojects.com/downloads/H491/combat.pdf D'Ann Campbell, "Women in Combat: The World War Two Experience in the United States, Great Britain, Germany, and the Soviet Union" ''Journal of Military History'' (April 1993), 57:301-323]{{dead link|date=January 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In the year 1975 the first female medical officers were appointed in the ''Sanitätsdienst'' of the Bundeswehr. Since 1994, two women, [[Verena von Weymarn]] and Erika Franke, attained the rank of ''Generalarzt''. But it was not until January 2001 that women first joined German combat units, following a court ruling by the [[European Court of Justice]]. There are no restrictions regarding the branch of service, and there are woman serving in the "Fallschirmjäger" and as Tornado fighter pilot. ===Ireland=== In the Irish [[1916 Rising]], Cumann na mBan, the women's wing of the Irish Volunteers, fought alongside them in the streets of Dublin and in the General Post Office, the Irish Volunteers' HQ. [[Constance Markievicz]], an Irish Revolutionary and suffragette, commanded male and female troops during the Rising. The Defence (Amendment) (No. 2) Act, 1979, allowed women to join the [[Irish Defence Forces]] for the first time and was passed by the [[Oireachtas]] in 1979, making them the first European Armed Forces to allow women all roles in the military including combat roles, and even join the Irish Army Ranger Wing (Fianoglach), the Irish Special Forces, similar to the British SAS.{{cite web|url=http://www.irishstatutebook.ie/1979/en/act/pub/0028/index.html |title=Defence (Amendment) (No. 2) Act, 1979 |publisher=Irishstatutebook.ie |date=1979-11-06 |accessdate=2013-10-07}} There are no restrictions for women to the "full range of operational and administrative duties."{{cite web|url=http://historical-debates.oireachtas.ie/D/0658/D.0658.200807020061.html |title=Dáil Éireann - Volume 658 - 02 July, 2008 - Written Answers. - Defence Forces Personnel |publisher=Historical-debates.oireachtas.ie |date= |accessdate=2013-10-07}} As of January 2010 the number of women in the Permanent Defence Forces is 565, 5.7 percent of the total.[http://debates.oireachtas.ie/DDebate.aspx?F=DAL20100224.xml&Page=1&Ex=1236#N1236 ]{{dead link|date=October 2013}} ===Italy=== [[File:Italian Soldier Olypmic Games Turin 2006.jpg|thumb|upright=0.8|left|Italian parachutist]] During the short life of the [[Italian Social Republic]] (World War II), the Female Volunteer Unit was introduced as an auxiliary service and they were knwown as Female Auxiliary Unit ({{lang-it|Servizio Ausiliario Femminile}}). The law that introduced this unit provided that its existence be limited to war periods.{{cite web|url=http://web.tiscali.it/RSI_ANALISI/34.htm|title=Decreto istitutivo del Corpo femminile|access-date=30 September 2012}} Its equivalent in Southern Italy during World War II, was the ''CAF'', {{lang-it|Corpo di Assistenza Femminile}}, that was on the side of the [[Allies]]. This unit was also dismissed at the end of the war. Those who belonged to this unit were equivalent to [[sub-lieutenants]] and wore military uniforms made in [[Great Britain]].{{cite web|url=http://www.museobadoglio.altervista.org/docs/forze.pdf|title=Forze del Regno del Sud|access-date=30 September 2012}} In 1959, the Female Police unit ({{lang-it|Corpo di Polizia femminile}}) was established. In 1981, Diadora Bussani was the first woman who asked to be admitted into the Naval Academy of [[Livorno]] ({{lang-it|Accademia navale di Livorno}}). She was born in 1962 in [[Trieste]] and started her struggle to join the academy in 1981. After being excluded from the application, Italy's regional administrative court upheld the appeal; however, Italy's State Council overturned the judgment. The enlisting of a woman seemed to be legally feasible because of Italian law Legge 1963 n. 66 which allowed the enrollment of women in public positions, but the State Council excluded the military because of biological differences between male and female human bodies. When she became famous and the case was well-known, the [[United States Navy]] symbolically granted her enlistment on 2 November 1982.{{cite web|url=http://www.bloogger.it/2018/06/italiane-in-armi/|title=Italiane in armi|date=5 June 2018|publisher=}} Voluntary female military service was introduced in 1999 with the Italian law Legge 20 ottobre 1999 n. 380, which introduced the possibility of being admitted to the army for women.{{cite web|url=http://www.informagiovani.it/frame/_donnemiliti.htm|title=Servizio militare femminile|website=www.informagiovani.it}} Italy was the last country among [[NATO]] members to allow women to join the army.{{cite web|url=http://www.carabinieri.it/Internet/Editoria/Rassegna+Arma/2004/Suppl_3/I+Sessione/01_Sessione_03.htm#3|title=L'impatto del servizio militare femminile. Un primo bilancio (Periodico Rassegna dell'arma dei carabinieri anno anno 2004, supplemento al n. 3/2004|publisher=}} Nowadays women are present in all branches of Italian armed forces, including the police, and [[Guardia di Finanza]], and they are also employed for military missions abroad.{{cite web|url=http://www.difesa.it/APPROFONDIMENTI/ARCHIVIOAPPROFONDIMENTI/SERVIZIO_FEMMINILE/Pagine/default.aspx|title=Ministero della Difesa|publisher=}} Before the year 2000, women were employed in war only as voluntary nurses inside organizations [[Croce Rossa Italiana]] and ''Corpo delle infermiere volontarie dell'ACISMOM''. 235º Reggimento fanteria "Piceno" is the training center for women inside the Italian army.{{cite web|url=http://www.esercito.difesa.it/organizzazione/capo-di-sme/comando-per-la-formazione-specializzazione-e-dottrina-dell-esercito/Scuola-di-Fanteria/Centro-Addestramento-Volontari/235-RAV-Piceno|title=235° Reggimento Addestramento Volontari|website=www.esercito.difesa.it}} ===Norway=== Women in Norway have been able to fill military roles since 1938, and during the Second World War both enlisted women and female officers served in all branches of the military. However, in 1947 political changes commanded that women only serve in civilian posts, with reservists allowing women to join them in 1959. Female personnel currently make up around 12% of the armed forces (2017).{{cite web|url=https://forsvaret.no/en/facts/the-armed-forces-in-numbers/personnel|title=Personnel|first=|last=Forsvaret|publisher=}} Between 1977 and 1984, the Norwegian Parliament passed laws expanding the role of women in the Norwegian Armed Forces, and in 1985 equal opportunities legislation was applied to the military. In 1995, Norway allowed women to serve on its military [[submarines]], and to this date there has been at least one female commander of a Norwegian submarine.{{cite web|url=http://www.nato.int/docu/review/2002/issue4/english/interview.html|title=Nato Review|publisher=}} The first was [[Solveig Krey]] in 1995.{{cite web|url=http://www.mil.no/fakta/start/menneskene/kvinner/ |title=Forsvarsnett: Kvinner |publisher=Mil.no |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} In 2015 conscription was extended to women making Norway the first [[NATO]] member and first European country to make national service compulsory for both men and women.{{cite web |url=https://forsvaret.no/en/newsroom/news-stories/female-conscription |title=Universal Conscription |publisher=Norwegian Armed Forces |date=11 June 2015 |access-date=25 June 2016 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160305005856/https://forsvaret.no/en/newsroom/news-stories/female-conscription |archive-date=5 March 2016 |dead-url=no}} ===Poland=== [[File:Zolnierki 1920.JPG|thumb|175px|Polish female volunteers during the [[Polish-Soviet War]]]] Women have taken part in the battles for independence against occupiers and invaders since at least the time of the [[Napoleonic Wars]]. During the occupation by the [[Nazi]]s, 1939–1945, several thousand women took part in the resistance movement as members of the [[Home Army]] and the [[Polish People's Army|People's Army]]. The Germans were forced to establish special [[prisoner-of-war camp]]s after the [[Warsaw Rising]] in 1944 to accommodate over a thousand women prisoners.{{cite web|url=http://www.polishresistance-ak.org/12%20Article.htm |title=Women in Home Army |publisher=Polishresistance-ak.org |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} In April 1938 the law requiring compulsory military service for men included provisions for voluntary service of women in auxiliary roles, in the medical services, in the anti-aircraft artillery and in communications. In 1939 a Women's Military Training Organization was established under the command of [[Maria Wittek]]. In present Poland a law passed April 6, 2004 requires all women with college nursing or veterinary degrees to register for compulsory service. In addition it allows women to volunteer and serve as professional personnel in all services of the army. As of June 30, 2007 there are 800 women in the army, of which 471 are officers, 308 non-commissioned officers and 21 other ranks, in addition 225 are in military training schools. Two active duty Polish women have achieved the rank of Colonel. [[Maria Wittek]] was the 1st Polish woman to reach the rank of General.[http://www.kadry.wp.mil.pl/artykul.php?idartykul=20 Women in army – in Polish] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090104013702/http://www.kadry.wp.mil.pl/artykul.php?idartykul=20 |date=January 4, 2009 }}[[:pl:Kobiety w Wojsku Polskim|in Polish]], Retrieved 2013-11-14{{Better source|reason=per WP:CIRCULAR|date=September 2015}} ===Russia=== {{Main|Women in the Russian and Soviet military}} [[File:Regiment from Petrograd.jpg|thumb|210px|[[Women's Battalion#1st Petrograd Women's Battalion|1st Petrograd Women's Battalion]] (1918)]] [[File:Military parade on Red Square 2017-05-09 028.jpg|thumb|Russian female cadets.]] During the [[First World War]], heavy defeats led to the loss of millions of [[Russian Empire|Russian Imperial]] soldiers. To psychologically energize morale [[Alexander Kerensky]] (leader of Russia of the [[Russian Provisional Government]]) ordered the creation of the Woman’s Death Battalion in May 1917. After three months of fighting, the size of this all-female unit fell from 2,000 to 250.{{cite web|url=http://www.spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk/Wdeath.htm |title=Women's Death Battalion |publisher=Spartacus.schoolnet.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} In November 1917, the [[Bolsheviks]] dissolved the unit. Shortly after Russia became part of the [[Soviet Union]] (see above for the role of woman in Soviet military) until December 1991. The current tally of woman in the Russian Army is standing at around 115,000 to 160,000, representing 10% of Russia’s military strength. ===Serbia=== {{commonscat|Military women of Serbia}} Although the Serbian armed forces were traditionally exclusively male (with exception of nurses and some other non-combat roles) there were some exceptions. Several women are known to have fought in the ranks in the [[Balkan Wars]] and the [[First World War]], often by initially hiding their gender to work around the draft regulations. The most notable of them was [[Milunka Savić]], the most decorated female combatant in history. In the [[Second World War]] [[Yugoslav Partisans|Yugoslav partisan units]] accepted female volunteers as combatants as well as medical personnel. After the war the practice was abandoned, but was reintroduced recently with professionalisation of the army. ===Sweden=== In the Military Articles of 1621, which organized the Swedish army, military men on all levels were explicitly allowed to bring their wives with them to war, as the wives were regarded to fill an important role as [[sutler]]s in the house hold organisation of the army: prostitutes, however, were banned.Sjöberg, Maria: ''Kvinnor i fält 1550-1850.'' [Women in Combat] Gidlund (2008) This regulation was kept until the Military Article of 1798, though the presence of women diminished after the end of the [[Great Northern War]]. In the Military Article of 1798, the only women allowed to accompany the army was the professional unmarried female sutlers, in Sweden named ''marketenterska''. Unofficially, however, there were females who served in the army posing as male the entire period, the most famous being [[Ulrika Eleonora Stålhammar]]. In 1924, the [[Swedish Women's Voluntary Defence Service]] (Swedish: Riksförbundet Sveriges lottakårer, commonly known as Lottorna) was founded: it is an auxiliary defense organization of the [[Swedish Home Guard]], a part of the [[Swedish Armed Forces]]. Since 1989 there are no gender restrictions in the Swedish military on access to military training or positions. They are allowed to serve in all parts of the military and in all positions, including combat.[http://www.rekryc.mil.se/article.php?id=11756 in Swedish, Retrieved 04-23-2007] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927045646/http://www.rekryc.mil.se/article.php?id=11756 |date=2007-09-27 }} Female personnel currently make up around 13% of the Armed Forces.Swedish Armed Forces http://www.forsvarsmakten.se/sv/om-myndigheten/vara-varderingar/jamstalldhet-och-jamlikhet/historik/ ===Turkey=== When Turkish history is examined, it is apparent that Turkish women have voluntarily taken tasks in the defence of their country, showing the same power and courage as men. [[Nene Hatun]], whose monument has been erected in the city of Erzurum (Eastern Turkey) because of her gallant bravery during the Ottoman-Russian War, constitutes a very good example of this fact. Besides providing nursery services, women also took main roles in combat in WWI.{{cite web |url=http://www.haznevi.net/Kavramoku.aspx?KID=589&KTID=6 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140913011056/http://www.haznevi.net/Kavramoku.aspx?KID=589&KTID=6 |archivedate=2014-09-13 |df= }} Furthermore, the Independence War has taken its place in history with the unsurpassed heroism of Turkish women.http://www.nato.int/ims/2001/win/turkey.htm [[Sabiha Gökçen]] was the first female combat pilot in the world, as well as the first Turkish female aviator. She was one of the eight adoptive children of [[Mustafa Kemal Atatürk]]. Throughout her career in the Turkish Air Force, Gökçen flew 22 different types of aircraft for more than 8,000 hours, 32 hours of which were active combat and bombardment missions. She was selected as the only female pilot for the poster of "20 Greatest Aviators in History" published by the United States Air Force in 1996.{{cite web|url=http://www.ctie.monash.edu.au/hargrave/gokcen.html |title=Sabiha Gokcen (1913-2001), Pioneer Aviatrix |publisher=Ctie.monash.edu.au |date= |accessdate=2013-11-14}} Women personnel are being employed as officers in the Turkish Armed Forces today. The women officers serve together with the men under the same respective chains of command. The personnel policy regarding women in the Turkish Armed Forces is based on the principle of "needing qualified women officers in suitable branches and ranks" to keep pace with technological advancements in the 21st century. Women civilian personnel have been assigned to the headquarters staff, technical fields, and social services without sexual discrimination. Women officers serve in all branches except armor, infantry, and submarines. Assignments, promotions and training are considered on an equal basis with no gender bias. As of the year 2005, the number of the female officers and NCOs in the Turkish Armed Forces is 1245.http://www.nato.int/ims/2005/win/national_reports/turkey.pdf ===Ukraine=== [[File:Olena Stepanivin in 1915.jpg|thumb|125px|Olena Stepaniv of the [[Sich Riflemen]] II women's auxiliary subunit]] {{See also|Women in the Russian and Soviet military}} Women (on active duty) make almost 13% of the [[Armed Forces of Ukraine]] (18.000 persons); 7% of those are officers.[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/guide/general/detail/66664/ Ukraine’s few, proud female soldiers], [[Kyiv Post]] (May 13, 2010) This number is close to [[NATO]] armies statistics. Ukraine shows better results in military gender equality than countries like [[Army of Norway|Norway]] (7%) or [[Armed Forces of the United Kingdom|United Kingdom]] (9%). There are few female high officers, 2,9% (1.202 women).[http://www.undp.org.ua/en/media/41-democratic-governance/814-undp-helps-ukrainian-ministry-of-defence-create-new-opportunities-for-women UNDP helps Ukrainian Ministry of Defence create new opportunities for women] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120226062942/http://www.undp.org.ua/en/media/41-democratic-governance/814-undp-helps-ukrainian-ministry-of-defence-create-new-opportunities-for-women |date=2012-02-26 }}, [[UNDP]] (June 16, 2009) There are no females among Ukraine’s generals while there are a dozen female colonels. Contractual military service counts for almost 44% of women. However, this is closely linked to the low salary of such positions: men refuse to serve in these conditions when women accept them. In total about 25 percent of Ukraine’s 200,000 military personnel are women. Servicewomen live in woman-only apartments near the [[military bases]]. A female officer can take three years’ maternity leave without losing her position.[http://www.whatson-kiev.com/index.php?go=News&in=view&id=4176 Army Girls! Talking to Ukraine’s Female Soldiers], What's On (2009) ===United Kingdom=== [[File:The Auxiliary Territorial Service in the United Kingdom 1939 - 1945 H36315.jpg|thumb|right| ATS Searchlight Unit in the Second World War]] Women were first employed by the [[Royal Navy]] in 1696 when a handful were employed as nurses and [[laundress]]es on [[hospital ship]]s. They received pay equal to an [[Able Seaman (rank)|able seaman]]. The practice was always controversial and over the next two centuries first the nurses and the laundresses were removed from service. By the start of the 19th century both roles had been eliminated.{{cite book |title=Female Tars: Women Aboard Ship in the Age of Sail |last=Stark |first=Suzanne J. |year=1998 |publisher=Pimlico |isbn=978-0-7126-6660-2 |pages=68–71 }} Female service in the Royal Navy restarted 1884 when the Naval Nursing Service was formed. It became the [[Queen Alexandra's Royal Naval Nursing Service]] in 1902 and is still in operation. Women have had active roles in the British Army since 1902, when the [[Queen Alexandra's Royal Army Nursing Corps]] was founded. The [[Princess Mary's Royal Air Force Nursing Service]] was formed in 1918. During the Second World War, about 600,000 women served in the three British women's auxiliary services: the [[Auxiliary Territorial Service]], the [[Women's Auxiliary Air Force]], and the [[Women's Royal Naval Service]], as well as the nursing corps.Lucy Milks, ''Women in the British Army: War and the Gentle Sex, 1907–1948'' (2006) In 1917, the [[Queen Mary's Army Auxiliary Corps]] was formed; 47,000 women served until it was disbanded in 1921. The [[Women's Royal Naval Service]] (WRNS) was formed in 1917 as well. Before it disbanded in 1919, it provided catering and administrative support, communications and electrician personnel. In 1938, the [[Auxiliary Territorial Service]] (ATS) was created, with 20,000 women serving in non-combat roles during World War II, including as [[military police]]. They also performed a combat role on British soil, as [[anti-aircraft gun]]ners against the [[Luftwaffe]]. In 1949, women were officially recognized as a permanent part of British Armed forces, although full combat roles were still restricted to men. In this year, the [[Women's Royal Army Corps]] was created to replace the ATS, and in 1950 the ranks were normalised with the ranks of men serving in the British Army. From 1949 to 1992, thousands of women served in the WRAC and sister institutions.Nancy Goldman, ed. ''Female Soldier: Combatants or Non-Combatants? Historical and Contemporary Perspectives'' (1982) Women first became eligible to pilot [[Royal Air Force]] combat aircraft in 1989.{{cite news |title=Women on the frontline |first=Helen |last=Weathers |newspaper=[[Daily Mail]] |location=London |date=16 July 2001 |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-60478/Women-frontline.html}} The following year, they were permitted to serve on Royal Navy warships. Since 1990, women have successfully served as Royal Navy [[clearance diver]]s.{{cite news |title=Royal Navy's first woman warship commander Sarah West takes up her post |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-scotland-edinburgh-east-fife-18158980 | publisher=BBC News | date=22 May 2012}}{{cite news |title='Long, hard struggle' for green beret |publisher=BBC News |date=31 May 2002 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/scotland/2017213.stm |accessdate=23 December 2012}} The 1991 Gulf War marked the first deployment of British women in combat operations since 1945. After 1992, the women were integrated into regular Army units.{{cn|date=June 2018}} As of 2010, female personnel made up around 9% of the British armed forces.{{cite web |title=Factsheet: Women in the Armed Forces |url=http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/FactSheets/WomenInTheArmedForces.htm |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100308013733/http://www.mod.uk/DefenceInternet/FactSheets/WomenInTheArmedForces.htm |archivedate=8 March 2010 |location=United Kingdom |publisher=[[Ministry of Defence (United Kingdom)|Ministry of Defence]] |date=March 8, 2010 }} The [[2007 Iranian seizure of Royal Navy personnel|seizure]] of Royal Navy sailor [[Faye Turney]] in 2007 by the [[Navy of the Army of the Guardians of the Islamic Revolution|naval forces of the Iranian Revolutionary Guard]] led to some media comment on the role of women and mothers in the armed forces.{{Cite news |first=Sarah |last=Sands |date=2007-04-01 |title=Sarah Sands: Only the capture of Prince Harry could have done more damage |url=http://comment.independent.co.uk/commentators/article2411286.ece |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090222021935/http://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/sarah-sands/sarah-sands-only-the-capture-of-prince-harry-could-have-done-more-damage-442716.html |archivedate=22 February 2009 |deadurl=yes |work=[[The Independent]] | location=London |accessdate=2007-04-04}} In December 2015, it was announced that women would be permitted to begin training in autumn 2016 in order to enter all roles by the end of that year.{{cite news |title=British Army's women soldiers to go into combat |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |location=London |date=20 December 2015 |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/defence/12060225/British-Armys-women-soldiers-to-go-into-combat.html |accessdate=6 February 2016}} In 2016 a ban on women serving in [[close combat]] roles in the British military was lifted by Prime Minister David Cameron.{{cite news |title=Women to serve in close combat roles in the British military |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-36746917 |publisher=BBC News |date=8 July 2016 |accessdate=2016-07-08}} In 2017 the Royal Air Force's ground-fighting force became open to women for the first time, making the RAF the first branch of the British military to open every role to female service personnel.{{cite web|author=Danny Boyle |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/09/01/raf-becomes-first-branch-british-military-open-every-role-women/ |title=RAF becomes first branch of British military to open every role to women |publisher=Telegraph.co.uk |date=2017-09-01 |accessdate=2017-09-15}} In 2018, women became allowed to apply for all roles in the British military.{{cite web|author=Lizzie Dearden Home Affairs Correspondent @lizziedearden |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/women-soldiers-army-military-sas-defence-government-infantry-frontline-gavin-williamson-female-a8601371.html |title=Women now allowed to apply for Royal Marines and all other frontline military roles, defence secretary announces |publisher=The Independent |date= |accessdate=2018-10-25}} ==North America== ===Canada=== [[File:CWAC mechanic, 1944.jpg|thumb|upright|Private Lowry, [[Canadian Women's Army Corps|CWAC]], tightening up the springs on the front of her vehicle, Chelsea & Cricklewood Garage, England, 7 July 1944.]] During the First World War, over 2,300 women served overseas in the Canadian Army Medical Corps. During the Second World War, 5,000 women of the Royal Canadian Army Medical Corps again served overseas, however they were not permitted to serve on combat warships or in combat teams. The Canadian Army Women's Corps was created during the Second World War, as was the Royal Canadian Air Force (Women's Division). As well, 45,000 women served as support staff in every theatre of the conflict, driving heavy equipment, rigging parachutes, and performing clerical work, telephone operation, laundry duties and cooking. Some 5,000 women performed similar occupations during Canada's part in the [[Korean War]] of 1950–1953. In 1965 the Canadian government decided to allow a maximum of 1,500 women to serve directly in all three branches of its armed forces, and the former "women's services" were disbanded. In 1970 the government created a set of rules for the armed forces designed to encourage equal opportunities. In 1974 the first woman, Major Wendy Clay, earned her pilot's wings in the newly integrated [[Canadian Forces]]. Between 1979 and 1985 the role of women expanded further, with military colleges allowing women to enroll. In 1982 laws were passed ending all discrimination in employment, and combat related roles in the Canadian armed forces were opened for women, with the exception of the submarine service. In 1986 further laws were created to the same effect. The following years saw Canada's first female infantry soldier, and a female [[Brigadier-General]]. In 1989, a tribunal appointed under the Canadian Human Rights Act ordered full integration of women in the Canadian Armed Forces "with all due speed", at least within the next ten years. Only submarines were to remain closed to women.Ellen Symons, "Under Fire: Canadian Women in Combat," ''Canadian Journal of Women and the Law'' (1990) 4: 477–511 Women were permitted to serve on board Canadian submarines in 2002 with the acquisition of the [[Upholder/Victoria-class submarine|''Victoria''-class submarine]]. Master Seaman Colleen Beattie became the first [[Submarine#Women|female submariner]] in 2003. Canadian women have also commanded large infantry units and Canadian warships. Commander Josée Kurtz is the first woman appointed to command a major warship – [[HMCS Halifax (FFH 330)|HMCS Halifax]].{{cite web|url=http://www.forces.gc.ca/en/news/article.page?doc=canadian-armed-forces-historical-milestones-of-women/hie8w7rl|title=National Defence - Canadian Armed Forces - Fact Sheet - Canadian Armed Forces – Historical milestones of women|first=Government of Canada, National|last=Defence|website=www.forces.gc.ca}} On May 17, 2006 [[Captain (Canadian army and air force)|Captain]] [[Nichola Goddard]] became the first Canadian woman killed in combat during operations in [[Afghanistan]]. ===United States=== {{See also|Timeline of women in warfare in Colonial America|Timeline of women in warfare in the United States before 1900|Timeline of women in warfare in the United States from 1900 to 1949|Timeline of women in warfare in the United States from 1950 to 1999|Timeline of women in warfare and the military in the United States, 2000–2010|Timeline of women in warfare and the military in the United States from 2011–present}} [[File:080930-110605 - SGT Lisa Morales awaits turn.jpg|thumb|Two female U.S. Army soldiers in September 2008.]] [[File:C-130 - First all female crew.jpg|right|thumb|From 2005, the first all female [[C-130 Hercules]] crew to serve a combat mission for the [[United States Air Force|U.S. Air Force]].{{cite news |last=Johnson |first=Michael G. |date=2005-09-27 |url=http://www.defendamerica.mil/articles/sep2005/a092705wm3.html |title=First All-female Crew Flies Combat Mission |work=Defend America |publisher=[[United States Department of Defense]] |accessdate=2006-07-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060630032514/http://defendamerica.mil/articles/sep2005/a092705wm3.html |archivedate=2006-06-30 |df= }}]] [[File:JessicaLynch02.jpeg|thumb|United States Army prisoner of war, Private First Class [[Jessica Lynch]], after being rescued in 2003, during the early stages of the [[Iraq War]].]] [[File:100802-M-0301S-106 HM2 Claire E. Ballante, left, assigned to the Female Engagement Team (FET), patrols with 1st Battalion 2d Marines in Musa Qa'leh, Afghanistan.jpg|thumb|right|A U.S. Navy [[Hospital corpsman|corpsman]] with the Female Engagement Team, patrolling a street in Afghanistan with [[1st Battalion, 2nd Marines]], in August 2010.]] The first female American soldier was [[Deborah Sampson]] of [[Massachusetts]]. She enlisted as a [[Continental Army]] soldier under the name of "Robert Shurtliff". She served for three years in the [[American Revolutionary War|Revolutionary War]] and was wounded twice; she cut a musket ball out of her own thigh so no doctor would find out she was a woman. During the [[American Civil War]], [[Sarah Rosetta Wakeman]] enlisted under the alias of Private Lyons Wakeman. In the history of women in the military, there are records of female U.S. Revolutionary and Civil War soldiers who enlisted using male pseudonyms, but a letter written by [[Annie Oakley]] to President [[William McKinley]] on April 5, 1898 may represent the earliest documentary proof of a political move towards recognizing a woman's right to serve in the United States military. Oakley, sharpshooter and star in the [[Buffalo Bill]] [[Wild West Shows|Show]], wrote a letter to [[President of the United States|President]] [[William McKinley]] on April 5, 1898 "offering the government the services of a company of 50 'lady sharpshooters' who would provide their own arms and ammunition should war break out with Spain."{{cite web |url=https://www.archives.gov/research/recover/example-02.html |title=Letter to President William McKinley from Annie Oakley |last=Oakley |first=Oakley |authorlink=Annie Oakley |date=5 April 1898 |publisher=[[National Archives and Records Administration]] |accessdate=23 December 2012}} The [[Spanish–American War]] did occur, but Oakley's offer was not accepted. During [[World War I]], 21,498 U.S. Army nurses (military nurses were all women then) served in military hospitals in the United States and overseas. Eighteen African-American Army nurses served stateside caring for German prisoners of war ([[POWs]]) and African-American soldiers; after the Armistice, Nov. 11, 1918, they entered the Army Nurse Corps and cared for people. They were assigned to [[Camp Grant (Illinois)|Camp Grant, IL]], and [[Camp Sherman, Ohio|Camp Sherman, OH]], and lived in segregated quarters while caring for German POWs and black soldiers. African-American women also served in World War I as U.S. Yeomen (F). Of the 11,274 U.S. Yeomen (F) who served from 1917 to 1921, 14 were black.{{cite book |title=Women's Roles and Statuses the World Over |author1=Stephanie Hepburn|author2=Rita J. Simon |publisher=Lexington Books |year=2007 |isbn=978-0-7391-1357-8|url=https://books.google.com/?id=vLOE6Rizq68C&pg=PA25&lpg=PA25&dq=%2211274+%22+women+yeomen#v=onepage&q=%2211274%20%22%20women%20yeomen&f=false}} The first American women enlisted into the regular armed forces were 13,000 women admitted into active duty in the [[United States Navy|Navy]] and [[United States Marine Corps|Marines]] during World War I, and a much smaller number admitted into the [[United States Coast Guard|Coast Guard]]. The Yeoman (F) recruits and women Marines primarily served in [[clerk (position)|clerical]] positions. They received the same benefits and responsibilities as men, including identical pay (US$28.75 per month), and were treated as veterans after the war. The U.S. Army recruited and trained 233 female bilingual telephone operators to work at switchboards near the front in France and sent 50 skilled female stenographers to France to work with the Quartermaster Corps. The U.S. Navy enlisted 11,880 women as Yeomen (F) to serve stateside in shore billets and release sailors for sea duty. More than 1,476 U.S. Navy nurses served in military hospitals stateside and overseas. The U.S. Marine Corps enlisted 305 female Marine Reservists (F) to "free men to fight" by filling positions such as clerks and telephone operators on the home front. More than 400 U.S. military nurses died in the line of duty during World War I. The vast majority of these women died from a highly contagious form of influenza known as the "[[Spanish Flu]]", which swept through crowded military camps and hospitals and ports of embarkation. Women were quickly demobilized when hostilities ceased, and aside from the Nurse Corps the soldiery became once again exclusively male.{{cite web|url=http://www.uscg.mil/history/uscghist/WomenChronology.asp|title=Women's History Chronology|publisher=[[United States Coast Guard]]|accessdate=2011-03-11 }}{{cite web |title= Highlights in the History of Military Women |url= http://www.womensmemorial.org/Education/timeline.html |accessdate= 2011-03-11 |deadurl= yes |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110629034939/http://www.womensmemorial.org/Education/timeline.html |archivedate= 2011-06-29 |df= }}{{cite news|title=Women in the military — international|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/military-international/ |publisher=CBC News |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111014025906/http://www.cbc.ca/news/background/military-international/ |archivedate=October 14, 2011 }} The [[Women's Army Corps|Woman’s Army Auxiliary Corps]], the women's branch of the United States Army, was established in the United States on 15 May 1942 by Public Law 554, and converted to full status as the WAC on 1 July 1943. The [[WAVES|Woman’s Naval Reserve]] was also created during [[World War II]]. In 1944 women from the [[Women's Army Corps]] (WACs) arrived in the Pacific and landed in Normandy on [[D-Day]]. During the war, 67 Army nurses and 16 [[United States Navy Nurse Corps|Navy nurses]] were captured and spent three years as Japanese prisoners of war. There were 350,000 American women who served during World War II and 16 were killed in action; in total, they gained over 1,500 medals, citations, and commendations. Additionally, by the end of WW II, Women Ordnance Workers (WOWs) accounted for approximately 85,000 of all civilian employees, working for the [[Ordnance Corps (United States Army)|Ordnance Corps]].{{cite web|url=http://www.goordnance.army.mil/history/ORDhistory.html|title=History of the U.S. Army Ordnance Corps|website=www.goordnance.army.mil}} Ordnance soldiers ''and'' civilians worked across the globe, ranging from Iceland, Iran, the Pacific Islands, Africa, and Europe, to the Middle East. [[Virginia Hall]], serving with the [[Office of Strategic Services]], received the second-highest US combat award, the [[Distinguished Service Cross (United States)|Distinguished Service Cross]], for action behind enemy lines in France. Hall, who had one artificial leg, landed clandestinely in occupied territory aboard a British [[Motor Torpedo Boat]]. Law 625, [[Women's Armed Services Integration Act|The Women's Armed Services Act]] of 1948, was signed by [[Harry S. Truman|President Truman]], allowing women to serve in the armed forces in fully integrated units during peacetime, with only the WAC remaining a separate female unit. The WAC as a branch was disbanded in 1978. Women serving as WACs at that time converted in branch to whichever [[Military Occupational Specialty]] they worked in. U.S. servicewomen who had joined the Reserves following World War II were involuntarily recalled to active duty during the [[Korean War]]. More than 500 Army nurses served in the combat zone and many more were assigned to large hospitals in Japan during the war. One Army nurse (Major Genevieve Smith) died in a plane crash en route to Korea on July 27, 1950, shortly after hostilities begin. Navy nurses served on hospital ships in the Korean theater of war as well as at Navy hospitals stateside. Eleven Navy nurses died en route to Korea when their plane crashed in the Marshall Islands. Air Force nurses served stateside, in Japan, and as flight nurses in the Korean theater during the conflict. Three Air Force nurses were killed in plane crashes while on duty. Many other servicewomen were assigned to duty in the theater of operations in Japan and Okinawa.{{cite web|url=http://www.womensmemorial.org/Education/timeline.html|title=Highlights in the History of Military Women|website=Women In Military Service For America Memorial|accessdate=June 22, 2013|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HZVJCcKl?url=http://www.womensmemorial.org/Education/timeline.html|archivedate=June 22, 2013}}{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=scZN59DXeOwC&pg=PA204&lpg=PA204&dq=%22genevieve+smith%22+%22korean+war%22#v=onepage&q=%22genevieve%20smith%22%20%22korean%20war%22&f=false |title=Historical Dictionary of the Korean War |author=Paul M. Edwards |date= 2010-06-10|accessdate=December 18, 2011|isbn=9780810874619 }} Records regarding American women serving in the [[Vietnam War]] are vague. However, it is recorded that 600 women served in the country as part of the [[United States Air Force|Air Force]], along with 500 members of the WAC, and over 6,000 medical personnel and support staff. ''[[Frontiero v. Richardson]]'', {{ussc|411|677|1973}}, was a [[List of landmark court decisions in the United States|landmark]] [[United States Supreme Court]] caseTechnically, the case was decided under the [[Fifth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fifth Amendment]]'s [[Due Process Clause]], not under the Equal Protection Clause of the [[Fourteenth Amendment to the United States Constitution|Fourteenth Amendment]], since the latter applies not to the federal government but to the states. However, because ''[[Bolling v. Sharpe]]'', through the doctrine of reverse [[Incorporation (Bill of Rights)|incorporation]], made the standards of the Equal Protection Clause applicable to the federal government, it was for practical purposes an addition not to due process, but rather to equal protection jurisprudence. which decided that benefits given by the United States military to the family of service members cannot be given out differently because of sex. In 1974, the first six women aviators earned their wings as [[United States Navy|Navy]] pilots. The [[United States Congress|Congressionally]] mandated prohibition on women in combat places limitations on the pilots' advancement,{{cite news |title=Navy Woman Decries Limitations |agency=[[Associated Press]] |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1356&dat=19840823&id=kdgTAAAAIBAJ&sjid=iwYEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6981,4703933 |work=[[Star-Banner|Ocala Star-Banner]] |date=August 23, 1984 |at=vol. 40, no. 537, p. 8C|accessdate=23 December 2012}} but at least two retired as captains.{{cite journal |title=Woman Aviator Pioneer Retires |editor-first=E. Blake |editor-last=Towler |url=http://www.history.navy.mil/nan/backissues/1990s/1997/mj97/ppp.pdf |journal=Naval Aviation News |date=May–June 1997 |page=43 (electronic p. 4) |format=PDF |accessdate=23 December 2012}} In 1976 the [[United States Air Force Academy]], [[United States Coast Guard Academy]], [[United States Military Academy]] and the [[United States Naval Academy]] became [[coeducational]].{{cite web|url=http://www.usma.edu/dcomm/womenatwp/chronologyofsigeventsforwomenatusma.htm |title=Women at West Point: Chronology of Significant Events |publisher=Office of the USMA Historian |date=February 2006 |accessdate=December 18, 2011}} The United States Air Force then eliminated the [[Women in the Air Force]] program; with women more fully integrated with men in the service it was considered unnecessary. On December 20, 1989, Captain Linda L. Bray, 29, became the first woman to command American soldiers in battle, during the [[United States invasion of Panama|invasion of Panama]]. She was assigned to lead a force of 30 men and women [[military police]] officers to capture a kennel holding guard dogs that was defended by elements of the [[Panamanian Public Forces|Panamanian Defense Forces]]. The 1991 [[Persian Gulf War]] proved to be the pivotal time for the role of women in the United States Armed Forces to come to the attention of the world media. Over 40,000 women served in almost every role the armed forces had to offer. However, while many came under fire, they were not permitted to participate in deliberate ground engagements. Despite this, there are many reports of women engaging enemy forces during the conflict.{{cite web |url=http://userpages.aug.com/captbarb/femvetsds.html |title=Operations Desert Shield/Desert Storm |last1=Wilson |first1=Barbara A |publisher=American Women in Uniform, Veterans Too! |accessdate=23 December 2012}} The case ''[[United States v. Virginia]]'', in which the Supreme Court ordered that the [[Virginia Military Institute]] allow women to register as cadets, gave women soldiers a weapon against laws which (quoting Judge [[Ruth Bader Ginsburg]]) “[deny] to women, simply because they are women, full citizenship stature—equal opportunity to aspire, achieve, participate in and contribute to society”.[http://supreme.justia.com/cases/federal/us/518/515/case.html ''United States v. Virginia, et al.'' 518 U.S. 515 (1996)]. pp. 516, 532 (electronic pp. 2, 18). Retrieved 23 December 2012. During the [[Iraq War]] and the [[War in Afghanistan (2001–present)|Afghanistan War]], more than two hundred thousand women served, of which 152 were killed; of those 84 were killed by enemy action.{{cite news |title=Do women want the toughest fighting jobs? |author=Pauline Jelinek |agency=Associated Press |url=http://www.armytimes.com/news/2013/01/ap-women-want-toughest-fighting-jobs-010513 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130215132431/http://www.armytimes.com/news/2013/01/ap-women-want-toughest-fighting-jobs-010513 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=15 February 2013 |newspaper=Army Times |publisher=Gannett Government Media Corporation |date=5 January 2013 |accessdate=7 January 2013}} During the Iraq War, [[United States Army Reserve|U.S. Army reservists]] [[Lynndie England]], [[Megan Ambuhl]], and [[Sabrina Harman]] were convicted by [[court martial]] of [[Abu Ghraib torture and prisoner abuse|cruelty and maltreatment of prisoners]] at [[Abu Ghraib prison]]. During the Afghanistan War, American soldier [[Monica Lin Brown]], was presented the [[Silver Star]] for shielding wounded soldiers with her body, and then treating life-threatening injuries.{{cite news |url=http://www.defenselink.mil/news/newsarticle.aspx?id=49348 |title=Face of Defense: Woman Soldier Receives Silver Star |first=Micah E. |last=Clare |agency=[[American Forces Press Service]] |publisher=[[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] |date=24 March 2008}} In 2008, [[Ann Dunwoody]] became a [[Four-star rank|four-star]] general in the Army, making her the first woman in U.S. military and uniformed service history to achieve a four-star officer rank.{{cite news |last=Tyson |first=Ann Scott |title=Army Promotes Its First Female Four-Star General |work=Washington Post |date=November 15, 2008 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2008/11/14/AR2008111400259.html?hpid=sec-nation |accessdate=November 15, 2008}} Prior to Dunwoody's promotion to general (O-10), the highest-ranking woman in the history of the uniformed services was [[Patricia Ann Tracey]], who, as a [[vice admiral (United States)|vice admiral]] in the [[United States Navy]], wore three stars and retired in 2004; [[United States Marine Corps]] [[lieutenant general (United States)|lieutenant general]] [[Carol Mutter]] received promotion in the same year (1996) as Tracey but retired earlier (in 1999). As of 2010, the majority of women in the U.S. army served in administrative roles.[http://www.statista.com/statistics/214877/occupational-roles-of-women-and-men-in-the-us-military/ Statistics on occupational roles of women and men in the U.S. military], U.S. Department of Defense, December 2011. Retrieved May 3, 2013. In 2011, Major General [[Margaret H. Woodward]] commanded [[Operation Odyssey Dawn]]'s air component in Libya, making her the first woman to command a U.S. combat air campaign.{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-29/libya-airstrikes-make-woodward-first-woman-to-lead-u-s-air-war.html |title=Woodward First Woman to Command U.S. Air Attack in Libya ‘No-Fly’ Mission |first=Peter S. |last=Green |publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.|Bloomberg]] |date=29 March 2011 |accessdate=23 December 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5yA6D7eXC?url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-29/libya-airstrikes-make-woodward-first-woman-to-lead-u-s-air-war.html |archivedate=23 April 2011 |deadurl=no}} The [[Ike Skelton National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2011]] directed the [[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] (DoD) to review the laws, policies and regulations restricting the service of female service members. As a result, DoD submitted the ''Review of Laws, Policies and Regulations Restricting the Service of Female members in the U.S. Armed Forces'', popularly known as the "Women in Service Review", to Congress in February 2012. According to the review, DoD intended to eliminate co-location exclusion (opening over 13,000 Army positions to women); grant exceptions to policy to assign women in open occupations to direct ground combat units at the [[battalion]] level; assess the suitability and relevance of direct ground combat unit assignment prohibition to inform future policy based on the results of these exceptions to policy; and further develop gender-neutral physical standards for closed specialties.{{cite book |url=http://www.defense.gov/news/WISR_Report_to_Congress.pdf |title=Report to Congress on the Review of Laws, Policies and Regulations Restricting the Service of Female Members of the U.S. Armed Forces (Women in Service Review) |author=Office of the Under Secretary of Defense Personnel and Readiness |authorlink=Under Secretary of Defense for Personnel and Readiness |date=February 2012 |location=[Arlington, Va.] |publisher=[[United States Department of Defense|Department of Defense]] |accessdate=23 December 2012}} In 2012, [[Janet C. Wolfenbarger]] became the first female four-star general in the Air Force.{{cite web|url=http://www.hanscom.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123304811 |title=Gen. Wolfenbarger receives fourth star, assumes leadership of AFMC |author=Kim Dawley |date=June 5, 2012 |website= |publisher=Air Force Materiel Command Public Affairs |accessdate=2012-06-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130224051202/http://www.hanscom.af.mil/news/story.asp?id=123304811 |archivedate=February 24, 2013 |df= }} [[Michelle J. Howard]] began her assignment as the U.S. Navy's first female (and first African-American female) four-star admiral on July 1, 2014.{{cite web|url=http://m.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/jul/1/michelle-j-howard-becomes-navys-first-female-4-sta/|title=Michelle J. Howard becomes Navy’s first female 4-star admiral|first=The Washington Times|last=http://www.washingtontimes.com|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stlamerican.com/news/local_news/article_766cbe98-0157-11e4-a01f-0019bb2963f4.html|title=Howard becomes Navy’s first woman, first African American four-star admiral|publisher=}} In December 2015, Defense Secretary [[Ash Carter]] stated that starting in 2016 all combat jobs would open to women.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/pentagon-nbc-news-all-combat-roles-now-open-women-n473581|title=All Combat Roles Now Open to Women|author=Jim Miklaszewski|publisher=NBC News}} In March 2016, Ash Carter approved final plans from military service branches and the U.S. Special Operations Command to open all combat jobs to women, and authorized the military to begin integrating female combat soldiers "right away."{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2016/mar/11/ash-carter-approves-final-strategy-women-military-/|title=Ashton Carter approves final strategy for women in military combat roles|website=The Washingtion Times}} In 2017, the first woman graduated from the infantry officer course of the Marine Corps; her name was not made public.{{cite web|url=http://thehill.com/policy/defense/352243-marines-congratulate-first-female-infantry-officer-graduate |title=Marines congratulate first female infantry officer graduate |website=The Hill |date=25 September 2017 |accessdate=2017-09-26}} ==South America== ===Argentina=== The [[Argentine Army]] first authorized women in their ranks in 1997, the Air Force in 2001 and the [[Argentine Navy]] in 2002.{{cite web|url=http://www.taringa.net/posts/imagenes/18275764/Las-mujeres-en-el-Ejercito-Argentino.html|title=Las mujeres en el Ejercito Argentino - Imágenes|date=14 November 2014|publisher=}} Since then, they were deployed in [[peacekeeping]] missions to Cyprus and Haiti. The first female [[Argentine Air Force]] combat pilot graduated in 2005.{{cite web|url=http://www.lanacion.com.ar/707876-buen-debut-de-la-primera-mujer-piloto-de-la-fuerza-aerea|title=Buen debut de la primera mujer piloto de la Fuerza Aérea|date=27 May 2005|publisher=}} ===Bolivia=== The [[Bolivian Air Force]]'s first female military pilot completed her solo-flight in August 2015.{{cite web|url=http://reyquibolivia.blogspot.com.ar/2015/08/silvia-rodriguez-primera-piloto-de-un.html|title=Silvia Rodríguez, primera piloto de un avión de combate boliviano|website=reyquibolivia.blogspot.com.ar}} ===Brazil=== The first participation of a woman in combat occurred in 1823. Maria Quitéria de Jesus fought for the maintenance of the independence of Brazil, and is considered the first woman to enlist in a military unit. However, only in 1943, during World War II, women officially entered the Brazilian Army. They were sent 73 nurses, 67 of them registered nurses and six air transport specialists. They served in four different hospitals in the US Army, all volunteered for the mission and were the first women to join the active service of the Brazilian armed forces. After the war, as well as the rest of the FEB, the nurses, most have been awarded, they won the official patent and licensed the active military service. ===Colombia=== Joanna Herrera Cortez became the first female Colombian fighter pilot in 2004.
